Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Expectation2: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation2: A new client casually requests basic operating tips during a routine check-in call.
Story: I glanced at the kitchen clock, the aroma of simmering stew filling the house. My daughter and grandkids would arrive any minute for our long-awaited family gathering. I’d promised to teach my granddaughter how to make her favorite cookies, and my son-in-law was counting on my stories from the old days. Just as I was setting out the plates, my phone buzzed. It was a new client, calling during my routine check-in. “Sorry to bother you,” he said, “but could you walk me through the basics of the new machine? I’m a bit lost.” I could hear the uncertainty in his voice, and I knew how important it was to make a good impression, to be reliable and helpful. But as laughter echoed from the driveway, my heart twisted. I wanted to be present for my family, to be the grandmother they expected, but I also felt the weight of my responsibility as a machine repairer. The phone felt heavy in my hand as I stood between the kitchen and the call, torn by the demands of both worlds.
